heading.title: DIVISION 4 SETTING ASIDE AND VARIATION OF JUDGMENTS [rr 36.15–36.18]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 4 SETTING ASIDE AND VARIATION OF JUDGMENTS [rr 36.15–36.18]

leg:heading.title: SETTING ASIDE AND VARIATION OF JUDGMENTS [rr 36.15–36.18]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.15] r 36.15 General power to set aside judgment or order (cf DCR Part 13, rule 1, Part 31, rule 12A; LCR Part 11, rule 1, Part 26, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: General power to set aside judgment or order (cf DCR Part 13, rule 1, Part 31, rule 12A; LCR Part 11, rule 1, Part 26, rule 3)

p.text: A judgment or order of the court in any proceedings may, on sufficient cause being shown, be set aside by order of the court if the judgment was given or entered, or the order was made, irregularly, illegally or against good faith.
A judgment or order of the court in any proceedings may be set aside by order of the court if the parties to the proceedings consent.

level.toc-caption: [36.15.5] Consent to set aside and consent judgments

heading.title: Consent to set aside and consent judgments

p.text: If the consent order has been obtained in circumstances where the client had not in fact authorised the compromise, or where there had been another material mistake, the consent order may be set aside: Romeo v Papalia [2012] NSWCA 221; BC201205506 at [80], [85] ; Waitema City Council v Mackenzie [1988] 2 NZLR 242 ; Neale v Gordon Lennox [1902] AC 465 ; Logwon Pty Ltd v Warringah Shire Council (1993) 33 NSWLR 13 ; Lewis v Combell Constructions Pty Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 528 , not following Easyfind (NSW) Pty Ltd (1987) 11 NSWLR 98 .

Where both parties consent and the rights of third parties are unaffected the court may set aside a final judgment: Permanent Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (Executor estate of Andrews) v Stocks & Holdings (Canberra) Pty Ltd (1976) 15 ACTR 45; 28 FLR 195 .
As to the position where an appeal is brought from a judgment entered by consent see Barder v Caluori [1988] AC 20 (death of one of the parties after judgment).

level.toc-caption: [36.15.10] Irregular or illegal judgment — substantial irregularity

heading.title: Irregular or illegal judgment — substantial irregularity

p.text: Irregularity, illegality and lack of good faith are alternative bases for the exercise of the power to set aside a judgment. The entry of judgment is irregular if it has occurred in contravention of, or without compliance with, the rules. The entry of judgment may also be relevantly irregular if it was based on an unenforceable consent Logwon Pty Ltd v Warringah Shire Council (1993) 33 NSWLR 13 at 28–30; 82 LGERA 158; (1994) 11 EPLJ 446b; BC9303911 or on a foreign judgment that has since been set aside: Remilton v City Mutual Life Assurance Society Ltd (1907) 24 WN (NSW) 177 ; Bell v Bell (1954) 73 WN (NSW) 7 . If the entry of judgment is irregular for any of these reasons there is no further requirement to establish that judgment was entered as a result of misconduct or dishonourable conduct: Roach v B & W Steel Pty Ltd (1991) 23 NSWLR 110 at 113D–114E ; Smith v Bundandan Enterprises (2002) 55 NSWLR 367; [2002] NSWCA 322; BC200205587 at [60]–[67] ; AVS Australian Venue Security Services Pty Ltd v Criminale [2006] NSWCA 368; BC200610504 at [35] and [71] per Basten JA, see also Kendell v Carnegie (2006) 68 NSWLR 193; [2006] NSWCA 302; BC200608855 at [44]–[50] per Bryson JA explaining Coles v Burke (1987) 10 NSWLR 429 at 437 .

A judgment will be considered to be irregular where it has been entered contrary to a material requirement of the rules: Arnold v Forsythe [2012] NSWCA 18; BC201200771 (claim failed to allege material fact involving condition precedent to payment obligation); Fenato v Cmr of State Revenue (2010) 78 NSWLR 20; 78 ATR 893; [2010] NSWCA 80; BC201002180 (claim for unpaid land tax and interest — failed to plead service of notices of assessment or due date for payment); Gregory’s Transport Pty Ltd v Ray’s Haulage Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 333; BC200810813 (application not supported by relevant affidavit of debt).

A judgment will also be considered to be irregular where there is material which strongly suggests that it has been entered for more than is due; Alexander v Ajax Insurance Co Ltd [1956] VLR 436; [1956] ALR 1077 (default judgment procedure inapplicable to the proceedings); Hughes v Justin [1894] 1 QB 667 (judgment amount ignored payments); HR Turner & Son Pty Ltd v Rhodes [1970] 1 NSWR 305 (judgment entered for more than was due); Workers' Compensation Nominal Insurer v Roland Building Services Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 13; BC200800171 per Campbell JA (winding up order set aside — debt had been paid at the time that the winding up order was made); Smith v Bundandan Enterprises (2002) 55 NSWLR 367; [2002] NSWCA 322; BC200205587 (judgment entered in reliance on ambiguous admission).

Other examples of irregular judgment include: Xenos v National Australia Bank Ltd [2007] NSWSC 973; BC200707532 (order made for payment of funds out of court without party being given an opportunity to be heard); Hoskins v Van Den-Braak (1998) 43 NSWLR 290; BC9801033 (defendant not properly served); Anlaby v Praetorius (1888) 20 QBD 764 ; Johnsen v Duks [1963] NSWR 730 ; Harrison's Timber Pty Ltd v Haster (1974) 3 ACTR 1 ; Cash v Wells (1830) 1 B & Ad 375; 109 ER 826 (default judgment entered contrary to agreement between parties); Miltonbrook Pty Ltd v Westbury Holdings Kiama Pty Ltd (2008) 65 ACSR 545; (2008) 26 ACLC 230; [2008] NSWCA 38; BC200802260 at [84]–[87], [102], [103] (company reinstated without adequate notice to affected person).

Where a judgment to which this rule applies has been obtained as a result of a plaintiff’s irregular conduct or breach of good faith the defendant is generally entitled to have it set aside, as a matter of basic justice: Anlaby v Praetorius (1888) 20 QBD 764 . (However, the general rule is subject to some qualifications — as illustrated in [36.16.15] .) Subject to those qualifications, usually no adverse terms should be imposed on a defendant (not even contingent terms such as that the costs should be costs in the cause): Anlaby v Praetorius (1888) 20 QBD 764 ; White v Weston [1968] 2 QB 647; [1968] 2 All ER 842 . However, delay in moving to set aside the judgment may be taken into account, and may justify imposing relevant terms: RT Co Pty Ltd v Minister of State for the Interior (1957) 98 CLR 168; 31 ALJR 818; BC5700730 .

level.toc-caption: [36.15.15] Irregular judgment — incidental irregularity and sufficient cause

heading.title: Irregular judgment — incidental irregularity and sufficient cause

p.text: The threshold limitation on the power to set aside a judgment is that its exercise must be based on “sufficient cause”. This limitation is consistent with the fundamental principle of the general finality of judgments: Perpetual Trustees Australia Ltd v Heperu Pty Ltd (No 2) (2009) 78 NSWLR 190; [2009] NSWCA 387; BC200910737 at [32]–[33] and [45]. It precludes exercise of the power for slight, or merely contentious, reasons: Kendell v Carnegie (2006) 68 NSWLR 193; [2006] NSWCA 302; BC200608855 at [45] per Bryson JA. It permits the exercise of the power where the irregularity goes to the basic nature of the asserted claim: Fenato v Cmr of State Revenue (2010) 78 NSWLR 20; 78 ATR 893; [2010] NSWCA 80; BC201002180 at [39], [61]–[63], [75], [84] (failure to plead due dates for payment — potential overstatement of claim); Arnold v Forsythe [2012] NSWCA 18; BC201200771 at [59], [84] (failure to plead material fact).

The general principle requiring irregularly obtained default judgments to be set aside does not apply either if the irregularity is inconsequential or where it is causally unrelated to the entry of judgment: Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Buffett (1993) 114 ALR 245 ; Fadelli Transport Industries Pty Ltd v Timor Transport Pty Ltd (1986) 39 NTR 10 . Consequently the exercise of the power is not appropriate where:

the foreshadowed defence is manifestly hopeless: Faircharm Investments v Citibank International Plc (The Times, February 28, 1998, CA), (defendant unable to resist an application for summary judgment);
the irregularity arises from an accidental (and remediable) slip or omission: Armitage v Parsons [1908] 2 KB 410 ;

the irregularity has been waived, or condoned: Perpetual Trustees Australia Ltd v Heperu Pty Ltd (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 387; BC200910737 (defendant conducted the proceedings without raising a “wrong party” defence);

the asserted “irregularity” relates to a substantive matter that was not raised as an issue in the proceedings: Avery v Saree Holdings Ltd [2012] NSWSC 463; BC201202871 (non-compliance with the enforcement notice provisions of the Consumer Credit (NSW) Code s 80);
the irregularity relates to the court’s procedural administration: Fox v Ashwin (1887) 8 LR (NSW) (L) 384 (where the court's bailiff had made a false affidavit of personal service).

The phrase “against good faith” is not susceptible of exhaustive definition. It relates to the circumstance in which the judgment was given, rather than the circumstances in subsequent opposition to the application to set the judgment aside: Kendell v Carnegie (2006) 68 NSWLR 193; [2006] NSWCA 302; BC200608855 (3 November 2006) , at [52]–[53], [60] per Bryson JA (Hodgson and McColl JJA agreeing).
A default judgment signed contrary to the terms of a contract between the parties is against good faith: Cash v Wells (1830) 1 B & Ad 375; 109 ER 826 (Court of Kings Bench).

A breach of a promissory representation is against good faith (Roach v B & W Steel Pty Ltd (1991) 23 NSWLR 110 at 113 (proceeding to judgment in the absence of notice to the defendant where the plaintiff ought to have known the matter was contested and the absence was due to some mistake)).
Transfers made to defraud creditors may be against good faith: Silvera v Savic (1999) 46 NSWLR 124 at 139 [76]–[77]; 9 BPR 16,881; [1999] NSWSC 83; BC9900357 .

Failure to make disclosure of admitted claim by secured creditor in procuring payment of funds out of court was against good faith and the order should be set aside: Xenos v National Australia Bank Ltd [2007] NSWSC 973; BC200707532 at [21] and following.
Entry of a judgment pursuant to a self-executing order where a prior warning has been given is not necessarily against good faith: Coles v Burke (1987) 10 NSWLR 429 at 437 .

The obtaining of an order in circumstances where information available on subpoena, potentially damaging to a case, is not brought forward, does not necessarily constitute lack of good faith: Shirriff v Nominal Defendant [1999] NSWCA 152; BC9903507 at [17] .

A mistake based on a matter not part of negotiations for settlement is insufficient to be against good faith: Kendell v Carnegie (2006) 68 NSWLR 193; [2006] NSWCA 302; BC200608855 (3 November 2006) at [16], [57]–[59], [61]–[62], (unilateral mistake based on previous representation (in particulars) — no action to conceal the change of circumstances — and no relevant discussion during the course of settlement negotiations).

level.toc-caption: [36.15.20] Fraud — setting aside judgment obtained by fraud

heading.title: Fraud — setting aside judgment obtained by fraud

p.text: An application to set aside a judgment on the ground that it was obtained by fraud ought to be made in separate proceedings: Flower v Lloyd (1877) 6 Ch D 297; Ainsworth v Wilding [1896] 1 Ch 673; Cole v Langford [1898] 2 QB 36; Wyatt v Palmer [1899] 7 QB 106; Hip Foong Hong v H Neotia & Co [1918] AC 888 ; Goldring v National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd (1916) 22 CLR 336 at 339 ; Kinch v Walcott [1929] AC 482 ; Jonesco v Beard [1930] AC 298 at 300; [1930] All ER Rep 483 ; Cabassi v Vila (1940) 64 CLR 130 at 147; [1941] ALR 33 ; Spooner v Spooner (1956) 73 WN (NSW) 353 ; Hillman v Hillman [1977] 2 NSWLR 739; cf McDonald v McDonald (1965) 113 CLR 529 at 533; [1966] ALR 496 ; Spies v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1991) 24 NSWLR 691 at 693, 696–7, 701 . In order to make out a claim to set aside a judgment on the basis that it was obtained by fraud it is necessary to show not only that the information would probably have affected the judgment that was obtained in the previous proceedings: Spies v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1991) 24 NSWLR 691 ; Munroe Schneider Assocs (Inc) v No 1 Raberem Pty Ltd (1992) 37 FCR 234; 109 ALR 137 ; but also that it was also not in contest in the earlier proceedings and was discovered after the judgment: McDonald v McDonald, above, CLR at 533 ; Boswell v Coaks (No 2) (1894) 86 LT 365 at 366, 368 ; Birch v Birch [1902] P 130 ; Wentworth v Rogers (No 5) (1986) 6 NSWLR 534; Boughen v Abel [1987] 1 Qd R 138. Mere suspicion of fraud is insufficient and the party seeking to set aside the judgment impugned must clearly establish the fraud alleged: Birch v Birch [1902] P 130 at 136, 139 ; McHarg v Woods Radio Pty Ltd [1948] VLR 496 ; Ronald v Harper [1913] VLR 311 ; and must show that the successful party was itself implicated in the fraudulent conduct: Ronald v Harper [1913] VLR 311 at 318 . A mere allegation of perjury by witnesses will not, except in exceptional cases, satisfy these requirements: Everett v Ribbands (1946) 175 LT 143 ; Cabassi v Vila, above,CLR at 147 ; Flower v Lloyd (1879) 10 Ch D 327; Baker v Wadsworth (1898) 67 LJQB 301 ; Perry v Meddowcroft (1846) 50 ER 529 . The principles to be applied in an application to set aside a judgment on the ground of fraud are summarised in the judgment of Kirby P in Wentworth v Rogers (No 5) (1986) 6 NSWLR 534 at 538; see also Tabain v Smith (NSWSC, Cohen J, No 5051/87, 7 August 1991, unreported, BC9101703); Boughen v Abel [1987] 1 Qd R 138 at 139, 146; Keele v Findley (1990) 21 NSWLR 444 . The plaintiff does not have to establish that “due diligence” would not have led to discovery of the fraud: Toubia v Schwenke (2002) 54 NSWLR 46; 36 MVR 159; [2002] NSWCA 34; BC200200540 ; nor does the plaintiff have to bear the costs of the first set of proceedings: Kennedy v Dandrick [1943] Ch 291 . If the judgment is sought to be attacked on the basis of the discovery of fresh evidence, as distinct from fraud, then the appropriate course is to proceed by way of appeal rather than by commencing separate proceedings: Re Barrell Enterprises [1972] 3 All ER 631; [1973] 1 WLR 19.

level.toc-caption: [36.15.25] Fraud — impugning foreign judgment obtained by fraud

heading.title: Fraud — impugning foreign judgment obtained by fraud

p.text: Enforcement of a foreign judgment may be stayed on the ground that it was obtained by fraud. But the same principles apply to such an application as those that would apply to the setting aside of a local judgment obtained by fraud. In both cases the applicant must establish that the fraud relates to matters that were “collateral or extraneous” to the issues that were determined on the basis of evidence (including the allegedly false evidence) adjudicated upon in the earlier proceedings. The fraud allegation does not jusify mere relitigation of the contested evidence in the earlier proceedings: House of Spring Gardens Ltd v Waite [1991] 1 QB 241; [1990] 2 All ER 990 Svirskis v Gibson [1977] 2 NZLR 4 at 10 ; Jacobs v Beaver (1908) 17 OLR 496 ; followed in Keele v Findley (1990) 21 NSWLR 444 (which declined to follow contrary English authority suggesting a greater freedom to challenge foreign judgments: Abouloff v Oppenheimer & Co (1882) 10 QBD 295 at 300, 302, 304, 305 ; Vadala v Lawes (1890) 25 QBD 310 at 316 ; Syal v Hayward [1948] 2 KB 443 at 447, 448; [1948] 2 All ER 576; Jet Holdings Inc v Patel [1990] 1 QB 335 at 344 ).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.16] r 36.16 Further power to set aside or vary judgment or order (cf SCR Part 40, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Further power to set aside or vary judgment or order (cf SCR Part 40, rule 9)

p.text: The court may set aside or vary a judgment or order if notice of motion for the setting aside or variation is filed before entry of the judgment or order.
The court may set aside or vary a judgment or order after it has been entered if:
it is a default judgment (other than a default judgment given in open court), or
it has been given or made in the absence of a party, whether or not the absent party had notice of the relevant hearing or of the application for the judgment or order, or

in the case of proceedings for possession of land, it has been given or made in the absence of a person whom the court has ordered to be added as a defendant, whether or not the absent person had notice of the relevant hearing or of the application for the judgment or order.
[subr (2) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[8], [9], effective 6 July 2007 ; Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[11], effective 8 October 2009]
In addition to its powers under subrules (1) and (2), the court may set aside or vary any judgment or order except so far as it:
determines any claim for relief, or determines any question (whether of fact or law or both) arising on any claim for relief, or
dismisses proceedings, or dismisses proceedings so far as concerns the whole or any part of any claim for relief.

[subr (3) am Amendment 13 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[10], effective 5 April 2007; Gaz 116 of 7 September 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 7 September 2007 ; Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 5 October 2007]

If notice of motion for the setting aside or variation of a judgment or order is filed within 14 days after the judgment or order is entered, the court may determine the matter, and (if appropriate) set aside or vary the judgment or order under subrule (1), as if the judgment or order had not been entered.
[subr (3A) insrt Gaz 116 of 7 September 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 7 September 2007]
Within 14 days after a judgment or order is entered, the court may of its own motion set aside or vary the judgment or order as if the judgment or order had not been entered.
[subr (3B) insrt Gaz 116 of 7 September 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 7 September 2007]
Despite rule 1.12, the court may not extend the time limited by subrule (3A) or (3B).
[subr (3C) insrt Gaz 116 of 7 September 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 7 September 2007]
Nothing in this rule affects any other power of the court to set aside or vary a judgment or order.

level.toc-caption: [36.16.5] Absence of a party — orders made in

p.text: Legislation cited in [36.16.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 22(3)(b)(ii).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 9.8(a).

heading.title: Absence of a party — orders made in

p.text: It is a fundamental principle that persons likely to be adversely affected by orders have a right to be heard: Cameron v Cole (1944) 68 CLR 571; [1944] ALR 130 ; Re Great Eastern Cleaning Services Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 278 ; Dahozo Pty Ltd v Oz-US Film Productions Pty Ltd (1997) 24 ACSR 739 . That right ought ordinarily be recognised, and given effect to, before any order is actually made: Greig v Australian Building Industries Pty Ltd (in liq) (2003) 21 ACLC 1565; [2003] QCA 298; BC200303847 ; BP Australia Ltd v Brown (2003) 58 NSWLR 322; 46 ACSR 677; [2003] NSWCA 216; BC200304438 (applications for extension of time to commence proceedings). Nevertheless there are occasions where, aside from a mere omission to provide due notice, orders are made in the absence of in interested person — for example where the urgency of the situation precludes prior notice, or where the person fails to attend despite notice having been given.

In any situation where orders have been made without notice and in the absence of the person affected, any party including one who obtained the order, may apply under the present rule: Nicholson v Nicholson [1974] 2 NSWLR 59; (1974) 4 ALR 212 ; and see Jacques v Harrison (1883) 12 QBD 136 . In the exercise of the power conferred by the present rule it will be relevant to consider the potential merits of the affected party’s position: see [36.16.15] and [36.16.20].

For the purpose of the rule plaintiffs and defendants are parties to the proceedings. Cross-claimants and cross-defendants are also parties entitled to notice — at least in the absence of any order for separate determination of the cross-claim proceedings: see CPA s 22(3)(b)(ii) and UCPR r 9.8(a)

If other persons are relevantly affected by an ex parte order they do not thereby become parties to the proceedings: Pickles v Gratzon (2002) 55 NSWLR 533; [2002] NSWSC 688; BC200204345 (ex parte orders for the examination of witnesses). Nevertheless, as persons likely to be adversely affected by the orders, they have a right to be heard: Cameron v Cole, above; Dahozo Pty Ltd v Oz-US Film Productions Pty Ltd, above. And they may appear to discharge or vary orders made in their absence: Hardie Rubber Co Pty Ltd v General Tire & Rubber Co (1973) 129 CLR 521; 47 ALJR 462 ; Owners of the SS Kalibia v Wilson (1910) 11 CLR 689 at 694 ; Bidder v Bridges (1884) 26 Ch D 1 at 9 per Lord Selborne and at 12 per Cotton LJ.
Legislation cited in [36.16.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 36.15, [36.15.20], r 36.16(3A), (3B), (3C), UCPR r 36.17.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 135.

The general rule is that the court may amend, vary or recall a final judgment before it has been formally entered, but that a court ordinarily has no power to set aside a final judgment that correctly reflects the court’s intended decision and intention and has been formally entered: DJL v Central Authority (2000) 201 CLR 226 at 245; 170 ALR 659; [2000] HCA 17; BC200001746 at [38] ; University of Wollongong v Metwally (No 2) (1985) 60 ALR 68; 59 ALJR 481 at 483; BC8501097 ; Bailey v Marinoff (1971) 125 CLR 529; [1972] ALR 259; (1971) 45 ALJR 598; BC7100470 (self executing order for dismissal); Gamser v Nominal Defendant (1977) 136 CLR 145; 13 ALR 387; 51 ALJR 315; BC7700032 ; Re Suffıeld [1886–90] All ER Rep 276; (1888) 20 QBD 693 ; Meehan v Glazier Holdings Pty Ltd (2002) 54 NSWLR 146; [2002] NSWCA 22; BC200200709 (order for common form accounts, and payment, cannot be altered to direct accounts be taken on the basis of wilful default); Burrell v R (2008) 238 CLR 218; 248 ALR 428; [2008] HCA 34; BC200806864 (a decision that prompted the subsequent addition of UCPR r 36.16(3A) , (3B) , (3C) ).

This rule specifies several exceptions to that general rule — namely, (i) default judgments (ii) judgments given in the absence of persons entitled to attend and (iii) within 14 days after formal entry.

Other qualifications to the general principle are dealt with in UCPR r 36.15 (irregularly obtained judgments) [36.15.20] (setting aside a final judgment on the basis of either fraud or fresh evidence; UCPR r 36.16(3A) and (3B) recall or vary a judgment within 14 days of entry [36.16.53] ; UCPR r 36.17 (the “slip” rule), [36.17.15] (limited inherent jurisdiction) and CPA s 135 and [36.16.80] (relating to post-judgment events).

level.toc-caption: [36.16.12] Costs arguments after judgment has been formally entered

p.text: Legislation cited in [36.16.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.16(3), r 36.16(3A).

heading.title: Costs arguments after judgment has been formally entered

p.text: Parties who seek special costs orders after the determination of the proceedings should apprise the court of their intention when judgment has been delivered and either seek specific directions about the entry of judgment or file a Notice of Motion within 14 days. If a special costs application is not formally made in a timely manner, the court may lack the power to entertain the application: Kekatos v Stafford [2009] NSWCA 219 at [107]; BC200906610 ; Coastwide Fabrication & Erection Pty Ltd v Honeysett (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 291; BC200908575 at [13]–[15] (untimely application to vary a costs order — application dismissed).

UCPR r 36.16(3) contains an additional power to alter judgments or orders that neither determine any claim for relief, nor any question arising on any such claim. This provision is unlikely to be construed as conferring a power, additional to that contained in UCPR r 36.16(3A) , to make, or vary, a special costs order: Habib v Nationwide News Pty Limited (No 2) [2010] NSWCA 291; BC201010652 at [34]–[39]; Roads and Traffic Authority of NSW v Palmer (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 140; BC200502986 at [20]–[21].

Different views have been expressed as to whether the rule dispensation power conferred by CPA s 14 could permit the court to alter costs orders in response to an untimely application. These differing views reflect the ambiguity inherent in the terms of UCPR r 36.16(3A) — as to whether it imposes a requirement on an applicant party to file a timely notice of motion, or conditions the proper exercise of the power to the contingency of a timely application having been made: see [s 14.3]. In some cases where parties orally gave timely notice, the court expressed the view that CPA s 14 permitted dispensation with the requirement to file a formal notice of motion: Roads and Traffic Authority of NSW v Refrigerated Roadways Pty Ltd (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 336; BC200909397 at [10]; Hancock v Arnold (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 19; BC200900800 at [11]; Spina v Permanent Custodians Ltd (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 419; BC200911620 at [9]. However, at least in the absence of timely oral notice, there is a conceptual difficulty in purporting to “dispense” with a requirement that is expressed as a condition precedent to the exercise of the substantive power: see AT v Commissioner of Police (No 2) [2010] NSWCA 337; BC201009426 at [9]–[13].
Legislation cited in [36.16.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 2, rr 16.1–16.10, r 16.3(1A).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 58, s 59.

A default judgment for the purposes of the present rule is a judgment given for a plaintiff in the circumstances provided for in UCPR rr 16.1–16.10 . Typically those circumstances will involve judgment being given in the absence, and potentially without formal notice to, the defaulter: see UCPR r 16.3(1A) . (If default judgment is given in open court in the presence of the defaulter the present rule does not apply.)

In the exercise of the discretion conferred by this rule the task of the court is to balance the competing interests of the plaintiff and the defendant and to determine whether or not the interests of justice require that the defendants should be permitted to contest the plaintiff’s claim: Reinehr Industrial Lease & Finance Pty Ltd v Jordan (NSWCA, 4 June 1974, Street ACJ, Hardie and Glass JJA, unreported, BC7400068); Stollznow v Calvert [1980] 2 NSWLR 749 at 751 ; Adams v Kennick Trading (Int) Ltd (1986) 4 NSWLR 503; 10 ALN N47 ; Garrard (t/as Arthur Anderson & Co) v Email Furniture Pty Ltd (1993) 32 NSWLR 662 at 671 .
Factors that are relevant to the exercise of that discretion include:

the regularity of the judgment (or, more specifically, the nature and apparent materiality of any irregularity in the claim or the manner in which the default judgment was obtained) — see [36.15.10] and [36.15.15] ;

the reasons for the default which occasioned judgment being entered (including whether or not the plaintiff warned its intention to enter judgment: Pope v Aberdeen Transport Co Pty Ltd [1965] NSWR 1550 );
any delay in taking steps to have the judgment set aside;
whether that delay has operated to the prejudice of the plaintiff; and
the defendant’s apparent prospects of success in the proceedings: Grimshaw v Dunbar [1953] 1 QB 408 at 415; [1953] 1 All ER 350 ; Vacuum Oil Pty Co Ltd v Stockdale (1942) 42 SR (NSW) 239 at 244 .

As a general proposition it may be said that if the judgment has been regularly obtained, the court will require the defendant to show, by affidavit or otherwise, that they have a good defence on the merits, and also to explain the default which occasioned the entry of judgment: Vacuum Oil Co Pty Ltd v Stockdale (1942) 42 SR (NSW) 239 at 243; (1942) 59 WN (NSW) 188 ; Kostokanellis v Allen [1974] VR 596 ; Evans v Bartlam [1937] 2 All ER 646; (1937) 53 TLR 689; [1937] AC 473 at 480 (affidavit of merits required); Ex parte Vigilant Finance (NSW) Pty Ltd; Re Cameron Smith [1964] NSWR 1282 at 1285 (affidavit of merits required); Magnate Projects Pty Ltd v Youma Constructions (No 2) Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 331; BC200507177 at [15] per Hodgson JA; Akari v Sole [2008] NSWSC 59; BC200800483 .

That general proposition may require some modification in its application to setting aside a judgment or order that has been entered in the absence of a party. A judgment of that kind may be “regular” in the sense that the circumstances complied with all the formal requirements (for example of form and notice) but it is still liable to be set aside under UCPR r 36.16(2)(b). In applications of this kind it may be particularly relevant to consider taking into account whether the party’s absence was a result of agreement with, or misrepresentation by, the other party: Double Bay Newspapers Pty Ltd v Fitness Lounge Pty Ltd (2006) 57 ACSR 131; [2006] NSWSC 226; BC200602054 ; Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Annesley Plant Hire Pty Ltd [2010] FCA 755; BC201005063 ; or neglect by the party’s legal representatives: Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations v Murnkurni Women’s Aboriginal Corp (1995) 58 FCR 125; 137 ALR 404 . If the relevant application was duly served the mere fact that the order sought was made in the absence of an affected party does not itself suffice to justify the exercise of the power to set it aside: Northey v Bega Valley Shire Council [2012] NSWCA 28; BC201201162 at [17] and [29].

If the judgment is affected by irregularity, much will depend on the nature and apparent materiality of the irregularity: see [36.15.10]. The regularity of the original judgment may involve consideration of the capacity in which the judgment debtor was found liable. For example, a default judgment against an agent cannot stand when judgment is also recovered against the principal in circumstances where both are sued in the alternative. In such a case, the plaintiff must elect between the available judgment debtors: Petersen v Moloney (1951) 84 CLR 91 at 102–104; [1951] ALR (CN) 1056; (1951) 25 ALJR 566 ; Midas Management Pty Ltd v Equator Communications Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 255; BC200801995 at [76]–[80].

If the applicant seeks to show they have a defence on the facts, the supporting affidavit should be sworn by a person who can give direct evidence of the material matters. An affidavit sworn on the basis of information and belief only, such as an affidavit sworn by an instructing solicitor, will not generally be regarded as sufficient: Palmer v Prince [1980] WAR 61 ; Worldwide Products Pty Ltd v Hoffman [1982] Qd R 316 ; Sharples v Northern Territory (1988) 55 NTR 35; (1988) 91 FLR 11 . In a proper case, the court may permit cross-examination on the affidavit: Richards v High (1920) 37 WN (NSW) 262 .

In relation to the question of the defendant’s prospects of success, it is clear that on the hearing of an application to set aside judgment, the court is not concerned to embark upon the adjudication of the truth or otherwise of the case which the defendant seeks to make: Reinehr Industrial Lease and Finance Pty Ltd v Jordan, above; Adams v Kennick Trading (International) Ltd (1986) 4 NSWLR 503; 10 ALN N47 ; Cuttle v Brandt (1947) 64 WN (NSW) 96 at 98 ; Simpson v Alexander (1926) 26 SR (NSW) 296 at 301; (1926) 43 WN (NSW) 76 . Nevertheless the court must be satisfied that the defence is asserted bona fide: Grimshaw v Dunbar, above; and that there is an arguable or triable issue: Burns v Kondel [1971] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 554; Evans v Bartlam [1937] 2 All ER 646; (1937) 53 TLR 689; [1937] AC 473 .

So far as delay is concerned, there are differing views as to whether, on its own, it can provide a sufficient basis for refusing the application to set aside a default judgment. CPA s 59 , and the notes to both CPA s 58 and UCPR Pt 2 , emphasise the relevance of efficiency (and the desirability of compliance with procedural requirements) to such decisions. Other cases take the view that these general considerations are not sufficient to deprive individual litigants of a determination of the merits of their position, at least in the absence of irremediable prejudice to the opposing party: Davies v Pagett (1986) 10 FCR 226; 70 ALR 793 ; Byron v Southern Star Group Ltd (1995) 13 ACLC 301 ; Cohen v McWilliam (1995) 38 NSWLR 476; 128 FLR 263; BC9501910 .

level.toc-caption: [36.16.17] Setting aside summary judgment registered locally for enforcement when foreign judgment on which it was predicated set aside

heading.title: Setting aside summary judgment registered locally for enforcement when foreign judgment on which it was predicated set aside

p.text: Where a judgment is made entirely on the basis of a foreign judgment, and the foreign judgment is later overturned and set aside, good reason exists to set aside the judgment that relied on it: Benefit Strategies Group Inc v Prider [2007] SASC 250; BC200705155 .

A defendant’s apparent prospects of success are relevant in the exercise of the power conferred by the present rule. It is usual to annex a draft of the defence to the affidavit. It is usually said that what must be shown is a defence on the merits, but this merely means a good defence and defences such as infancy, the Statute of Limitations or illegality are defences on the merits: Rooke v Day (1907) 24 WN (NSW) 127 ; Commercial Traders Ltd v Furness [1962] NSWR 291; (1962) 79 WN (NSW) 528 ; Term Sales Pty Ltd v Joseph (1949) 67 WN (NSW) 44 ; Baxter v Harrigan (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 12 . Where the defendant is an executor and swears an affidavit that he or she finds it impossible to file an affidavit showing a defence on the merits at the current time because relevant facts are not within his or her knowledge, the court will not insist on an affidavit of merits: Collins Book Depot Pty Ltd v Bretherton [1938] VLR 40 . It is not, however, sufficient to swear that counsel has advised that there is a defence without more (Nash v Swinburne (1841) 133 ER 1293 ), nor is it sufficient that the deponent swears as to his or her belief in the existence of a defence; what must be shown are facts showing a good ground of defence: Saunders v Hammond [1965] QWN 39 .

After sequestration, a bankrupt has no locus standi to set aside a default judgment: WR Henry & Son v Hodge [1963] VR 111 . As to the situation where judgment is entered after service of bankruptcy notice, see Re Agrillo (1977) 13 ALR 635 ; Re Padagas; Ex parte Carrier Air Conditioning Pty Ltd (1977) 16 ALR 475; 30 FLR 170 . If the judgment was entered by default after the bankruptcy, but without notice to the bankruptcy trustee, it would be set aside as irregular: see Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth) s 60.

level.toc-caption: [36.16.30] Default judgment — delay in bringing application to set aside or vary

heading.title: Default judgment — delay in bringing application to set aside or vary

p.text: The application to set aside the judgment should be made as soon as possible after it comes to the defendant’s knowledge: Sevil v Heath (1877) Knox 359; North v Shierlaw (1897) 13 WN (NSW) 163 ; Rosing v Ben Shemesh [1960] VR 173 . Any delay in making the application must be satisfactorily explained: Term Sales Pty Ltd v Joseph (1949) 67 WN (NSW) 44 . The affidavit must be sworn by someone who has knowledge of the facts, but in the appropriate case it may be sufficient for the affidavit to be filed by the solicitor’s clerk: Migel v Bowles (1894) 10 WN (NSW) 172.

level.toc-caption: [36.16.35] Interlocutory orders — variation of interlocutory orders

heading.title: Interlocutory orders — variation of interlocutory orders

p.text: As a general principle, interlocutory orders may be varied or set aside in appropriate circumstances: Woods v Sheriff of Queensland (1895) 6 QLJ 163 at 164; Hutchinson v Nominal Defendant [1972] 1 NSWLR 443; Douglas v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 126; Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Tectran Corp Pty Ltd (No 15) (NSWCA, Full Court, 8 July 1993, unreported, BC9301787). Interlocutory orders involving matters of practice and procedure are always amenable to change whenever necessary for the proper conduct of the proceedings: Wilkshire v Commonwealth (1976) 9 ALR 325 at 330. On the other hand, orders may be classified as interlocutory, for the purpose of provisions requiring leave to appeal, even though they have the practical effect of determining the parties rights: Cooper v Williams [1963] 2 QB 567 at 580, 582 (stay of proceedings); Lambert v Mainland Market Deliveries Ltd [1977] 2 All ER 826; [1977] 1 WLR 825. In those cases, a purported application to vary the original order may involve, in substance, an impermissible attempt to appeal against the original order: Woodcroft v DPP (Cth) (2000) 174 ALR 60; [2000] NSWSC 228; BC200002079 (consent order under proceeds of crime legislation — no variation except by appeal).

Even where the variation application does not constitute an impermissible de facto appeal, the original interlocutory order may have been intended to govern the rights of the parties, or the conduct of the proceedings, until the final determination of the proceedings. In these types of cases, and especially where orders have been made after a contested hearing, the court ought not alter an interlocutory order unless there has been a material change in circumstances: Brimaud v Honeysett Instant Print Pty Ltd (1988) 217 ALR 44; BC8801491 . This is particularly the case where the interlocutory order has been made by an appellate court: Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden [1999] NSWCA 313 at [38]; BC9906206 (citing Brimaud , above, with approval). Subject to these limitations, an interlocutory order can be set aside even when it has been made by consent and entered: Mullins v Howell (1879) 11 Ch D 763 ; Ainsworth v Wilding [1896] 1 Ch 673.

level.toc-caption: [36.16.40] Interlocutory orders made by consent — variation of

heading.title: Interlocutory orders made by consent — variation of

p.text: An interlocutory order can be set aside even when it has been made by consent and entered: Mullins v Howell (1879) 11 Ch D 763 ; Ainsworth v Wilding [1896] 1 Ch 673 . Where orders are expressed to be made “by consent” it is important to bear in mind the inherent ambiguity in that expression: Chandless-Chandless v Nicholson [1942] 2 KB 321 at 324 ; National Benzole Co Ltd v Gooch [1961] 1 WLR 1489 (appeal set aside by consent with no order as to costs — binding agreement). Even in the case of orders made under a contractual agreement between the parties it may indicate merely the absence of an objection by one of the parties: Siebe Gorman & Co Ltd v Pneupac Ltd [1982] 1 All ER 377; [1982] 1 WLR 185 ; or it may indicate an actual contractual agreement between the parties. Even in the latter case, however, the court retains its control over the proceedings and may vary its interlocutory orders where the interests of justice require: Mullins v Howell (1879) 11 Ch D 763 at 766 ; Purcell v FC Trigell Ltd [1971] 1 QB 358; [1970] 3 All ER 671 ; RD Werner & Co Inc v Bailey Aluminium Products Pty Ltd (1988) 18 FCR 389; 80 ALR 134 ; Morgan v 45 Flers Avenue Pty Ltd (1987) 11 NSWLR 573 ; Hunter v Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia (NSWSC, Young J, 12 June 1985, unreported, BC8500760).

This rule confers a discretionary power to review, correct or alter any judgment that has not been entered: De L v D-G of Community Services (No 2) (1997) 190 CLR 207 at 215; 143 ALR 171 at 176 ; Harvey v Phillips (1956) 95 CLR 235; 30 ALJR 140 (power to set aside a judgment ordered, but not yet entered, pursuant to a compromise between the parties). But the power is subject to the significant limitation imposed by the public interest in maintaining the finality of litigation. That public interest requires great caution in the exercise of the power, especially where the variation sought would have the practical effect of re-opening the proceedings to enable a significant rehearing: Autodesk Inc v Dyason (No 2) (1993) 176 CLR 300; 111 ALR 385 ; Wentworth v Woollahra Municipal Council (1982) 149 CLR 672; 42 ALR 69 ; Wentworth v Rogers (No 9) (1987) 8 NSWLR 388 ; Re Barrell Enterprises [1972] 3 All ER 631; [1973] 1 WLR 19 ; Watson v Metropolitan (Perth) Passenger Transport Trust [1965] WAR 88 ; Murray v Figge (1974) 4 ALR 612 .

The exercise of the power depends on establishing that the existing judgment or order is affected by a misapprehension of law or fact: Elliott v R (2007) 234 CLR 38; 239 ALR 651; [2007] HCA 51; BC200709514 at [32] . This may include an error in failing to afford a party a proper opportunity to be heard: Autodesk Inc v Dyason (No 2) (1993) 176 CLR 300 at 301–2; 111 ALR 385; 67 ALJR 270 . The scope of any review or re-opening will depend on the nature of the error or misapprehension. But the power ought not be exercised to permit a general re-opening of the case: Smith v New South Wales Bar Assn (No 2) (1992) 176 CLR 256; 108 ALR 55 ; State Rail Authority v Codelfa Construction Pty Ltd (1982) 150 CLR 29 at 38 and 45; 42 ALR 289 (challenge to orders allegedly made without proper notice to the parties); Texas Co (A’asia) Ltd v FCT (1940) 63 CLR 382 at 457; 14 ALJR 32 ; Re St Nazaire Co (1879) 12 Ch D 88 ; Harvey v Phillips (1956) 95 CLR 235; 30 ALJR 140 ; Winrobe Pty Ltd v Sundin’s Building Co Pty Ltd (No 2) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Sheller and Cripps JJA, No 40614/91, 24 December 1992, unreported, BC9201383); Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Tectran Corp Pty Ltd (No 15) (NSWCA, Full Court, 8 July 1993, unreported, BC9301787); Government Insurance Offıce (NSW) v Rosniak (1992) 27 NSWLR 665 .

Furthermore, the power will not usually be exercised in favour of an applicant who was at fault in failing to raise the matter in issue at an earlier stage: Autodesk , above; Wentworth v Woollahra Municipal Council , above; R v Giri (No 2) [2001] NSWCCA 234 at [17]; BC200103326 ; Aktas v Westpac Banking Corp Ltd (No 2) (2010) 241 CLR 570; 273 ALR 118; [2010] HCA 47; BC201099577 (special costs order sought 5 weeks after judgment delivered — application not previously foreshadowed — no variation of costs orders).
Legislation cited in [36.16.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.17.

Apart from matters involving the mere correction of errors (as to which see UCPR r 36.17 and its accompanying notes) examples of instances where the power has been exercised can be found in the following cases: De L v D-G of Community Services (No 2) (1997) 190 CLR 207 at 215; 143 ALR 171 at 176 (costs issue overlooked by counsel); Smith v New South Wales Bar Assn (No 2) (1992) 176 CLR 256; 108 ALR 55 (mistaken assumption about the state of evidence); Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Tectran Corp Pty Ltd (No 15) (NSWCA, Full Court, 8 July 1993, unreported, BC9301787) (misapprehension about the basis of the trial judge’s reasoning — limited reconsideration); Pittalis v Sherefettin [1986] QB 868; [1986] 2 All ER 227 (misunderstanding of a material matter); Re Harrison’s Share under a Settlement [1955] Ch 260 (subsequent overruling of material authorities by the House of Lords); Bastow v Bagley and Co Ltd [1961] 1 WLR 1494 (inconsistent decisions by differently constituted courts of appeal); Dietz v Lennig Chemicals Ltd [1969] 1 AC 170; [1967] 2 All ER 282 (fresh evidence); Li Shi Ping v Minister for Immigration Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (FCA, Sheppard, Gummow and Carr JJ, 13 April 1995, unreported, BC9507264) (re-opening appeal because court had acted on a misapprehension of the facts); Fox v Cmr for Superannuation (No 2) (1999) 88 FCR 416; 167 ALR 197 (re-opening granted where parties failed to advert to applicable legislation); Smith v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (1996) 7 BPR 15,069 (issue overlooked, further argument allowed); Re Samuel [1954] Ch 364 ; James Lamont & Co Ltd v Hyland Ltd [1950] 1 KB 585 ; National Benzole Co Ltd v Gooch [1961] 1 WLR 1489 ; University of Wollongong v Metwally (No 2) (1985) 60 ALR 68 at 71; 59 ALJR 481 at 483 (application to re-open to argue constitutional validity of statute — refused); Allen v Taylor [1999] NSWCA 377; BC9907171 (new trial ordered on damages, order altered to permit determination of contributory negligence issues); Suttor v Gundowda Pty Ltd (1950) 81 CLR 418 at 437–8; 24 ALJR 298 (possible re-opening where discretionary defence depends on findings made in the judgment).

level.toc-caption: [36.16.52] Judgments and orders — variation of non-determinative aspects

p.text: Legislation cited in [36.16.52] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.16(3), r 36.17.

heading.title: Judgments and orders — variation of non-determinative aspects

p.text: Rule 36.16(3) confers an additional variation power that is exercisable irrespective of formal entry of the judgment or order. But this additional power is confined to variations that are ancillary to, and do not substantively affect, the actual determination of claims in the proceedings. The limited scope of the power suggests it has some analogy with the “slip rule” in r 36.17 , but the occasions for its exercise are not confined to instances of accidental mistake or omission. For example the rule permits variation of details in a judgment or order to accord with subsequently acquired information: Re Director General of the Department of Community Services (2004) 31 Fam LR 703; [2004] NSWSC 44; BC200401687 (adoption order — variation of child’s date of birth); Re Application of PMD [2004] NSWSC 556; BC200404013 ; Application of CMS & JTS [2006] NSWSC 47; BC200600441 (adoption order — variation of child’s date of birth); Saul v Lin [2007] NSWSC 782; BC200705612 (consensual variation of prior costs orders). In addition, the power to vary an order under UCPR r 36.16(3) empowers the court to discharge an existing order and substitute a different order: Douglass v Gillman (1990) 19 NSWLR 570; BC9002458 .

level.toc-caption: [36.16.53] Judgment entered — specific, limited power to alter

p.text: Legislation cited in [36.16.53] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.12, UCPR r 36.16(3A) and (3B), UCPR r 36.16(3A), UCPR r 36.16(3C), r 36.17.

heading.title: Judgment entered — specific, limited power to alter

p.text: The variation power in UCPR r 36.16(3A) is expressed to be conditional on timely filing of a notice of motion by the applicant party. The notice must set out the substance of the variation claimed, but it is not necessary that it specifically refers to the power conferred by the present rule: Cooper v Kinsella (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 140; BC201103878 at [10]. UCPR r 36.16(3C) precludes reliance on the general power in UCPR r 1.12 to extend the 14 day time limit. (Differing views have been expressed as to whether the dispensation power conferred by CPA s 14 could provide a basis for the exercise of the power, in the absence of a timely application: see [36.16.12] above.) This prohibition against any extension of time makes it clear that the 14 day period is not intended to be variable, and reflects the need for judgments and orders to be final and certain as to their operation: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Meredith (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 133; BC200804272 at [15] .
Legislation cited in [36.16.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 18.4.

The expression liberty to apply has at least two different uses. First it may, if the liberty permits interlocutory applications to be made on less than three days’ notice, operate simply as an abridgment of the time that would otherwise be required by UCPR r 18.4 and its accompanying notes. The second use of the term is to authorise applications to vary or supplement substantive orders. It is this second use of the term that is addressed in the following paragraphs.

Interlocutory orders frequently contain liberty to apply. Indeed they are implicitly subject to liberty to apply, because of the court's general duty and power to control its own procedure: Mullins v Howell (1879) 11 Ch D 763 at 766 ; Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd v Philip Morris Inc (1981) 148 CLR 170; 35 ALR 625 ; Wilkshire v Commonwealth (1976) 9 ALR 325 at 330; Penrice v Williams (1883) 23 Ch D 353 at 357 (ancillary discovery application in proceedings referred to arbitration); see also [36.16.35] . Liberty to apply in relation to interlocutory orders at least permits subsequent applications concerning the implementation and enforcement of those orders. And in an exceptional case (such as one involving an unsuccessful attempt to achieve an interim compromise of the proceedings: Bonnici v Kur-ring-gai Municipal Council (2001) 121 LGERA 1; (2002) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-631; [2001] NSWSC 1124 at [168]–[172]; BC200107793 ) liberty to apply may sometimes even have more expansive connotations.
Legislation cited in [36.16.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 65.

Liberty to apply in relation to a final order, is limited to matters concerning the implementation of the earlier order: Dowdle v Hillier (1949) 66 WN (NSW) 155 ; Cristel v Cristel [1951] 2 KB 725 at 730; Re Porteous [1949] VLR 383 ; Say-Dee Pty Ltd v Farah Constructions Pty Ltd (No 3) [2006] NSWCA 329; BC200609698 at [33], [35] (variation of receivers powers of sale). It does not extend to the substantive amendment of the judgment or orders in respect of which the liberty to apply was granted (Wentworth v Woollahra Municipal Council (NSWCA, 31 March 1983, unreported); Phillips v Walsh (1990) 20 NSWLR 206 at 209 ; Abigroup Ltd v Abignano (1992) 39 FCR 74; 112 ALR 497 (citing this note with approval); Thwaite v Thwaite [1982] Fam 1 (for example, liberty to apply does not permit setting aside an order previously made by consent); except in the case of orders for specific performance when the order cannot be carried out, for example, if the defendant is impecunious. (In that event the court may be asked to set aside its earlier order: Buckman v Rose (1980) 1 BPR 9558).

level.toc-caption: [36.16.70] Liberty to apply — further consideration reserved

heading.title: Liberty to apply — further consideration reserved

p.text: Apart from reserving liberty to apply, a judge may also reserve further consideration of the proceedings. This course of action may be appropriate, for example, where the proceedings, or some part of them, is referred to a master, where the judge has not finally dealt with all of the matters in dispute or, in exceptional cases, where the proceedings have been dealt with so urgently that there is a possibility of some matter having been overlooked. This course, rather than granting liberty to apply, should be adopted where an order is made for the taking of partnership accounts: Kraft v Kupferwasser (1991) 23 NSWLR 236 at 243 .

While the reservation of further consideration may give more scope to raise matters subsequently than would granting liberty to apply, it does not permit either party to re-litigate the matter: Le Grand v Whitehead (1826) 38 ER 120; Pritchard v Draper (1830) 39 ER 74; Lyne v Lyne (1856) 56 ER 553; Haviland v McLeary (1894) 15 LR (NSW) Eq 22 : see also New South Wales Egg Corp v Peek (No 3) (NSWSC, Young J, 13 June 1986, unreported). It is limited to consideration, including further evidence, of matters incidental to or consequential upon, the original judgment, and may include matters with which it did not fully deal: Rosser v Maritime Services Board (No 2) (1998) 14 BCLC 375; BC9604305 (assessment of damages involving additional factual findings).

Apart from clarification of the type permitted by “liberty to apply” circumstances may arise where it is necessary to obtain an authoritative interpretation of a judgment or order. The appropriate procedure is by way of summons for declaration: Australian Energy Ltd v Lennard Oil NL (No 2) [1988] 2 Qd R 230 ; see Young on Declaratory Orders, 2nd ed, para 1503. The court’s function on such a summons is merely to construe the prior judgment or order. In so doing, and unless the meaning is clear from the actual terms of the judgment or order, the court may consider the surrounding circumstances and use extrinsic material, including the pleadings, the course and content of the evidence, and the reasons for judgment: see Australian Energy Ltd v Lennard Oil NL (No 2) [1988] 2 Qd R 230 at 232 ; Repatriation Commission v Nation (1995) 57 FCR 25 at 33–4; (1995) 21 AAR 351 ; Owston Nominees No 2 Pty Ltd v Branir Pty Ltd (2003) 129 FCR 558; [2003] FCA 629; BC200303362 ; Yates Property Corp Pty Ltd v Boland (1998) 89 FCR 78; BC9806851 ; Hanave Pty Ltd v LFOT Pty Ltd [2000] FCA 388; BC200001414 at [7] (construction of ambiguous costs order).

It will often be appropriate for proceedings of this kind to come before the judge who made the judgment or order. But this is a matter of practical convenience rather than necessity and may not always be possible: Gikas v Papanayiotou [1977] 2 NSWLR 944 (Needham J made orders varying the terms of a decree made 9 years earlier by McLelland CJ in Eq); Ecrosteel Pty Ltd v Pefor Printing Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Santow J, 12 November 1997, unreported, BC9706087) (arguable conflict in original orders made by an acting judge whose commission had expired) Owston Nominees No 2 Pty Ltd v Branir Pty Ltd (2003) 129 FCR 558; [2003] FCA 629; BC200303362 (original judge had retired from the court).

The Supreme Court’s declaratory jurisdiction permit it to make declarations of this kind in relation to the judgments and orders of other courts. However, if those courts retain their own declaratory jurisdiction, that circumstance may afford a proper basis for refusing to exercise the power in particular cases: Fine Real Estate Network Pty Ltd v Howell (NSWSC, Young J, 4 December 1997, unreported, BC9706889) (Federal Court judgment).
Legislation cited in [36.16.75] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.12.

In Whistler v Hancock (1878) 3 QBD 83 an order was made dismissing an action unless a condition was satisfied within a specified time. The condition was not met in time and it was held that the action stood dismissed and the court had no power to extend the time within which the condition might be met. The case thus became authority for the proposition that there was no power to set aside a judgment entered pursuant to a self executing order nor to extend the time for compliance within the order. This proposition was adopted in numerous cases: Bailey v Marinoff (1971) 125 CLR 529; [1972] ALR 259 (dismissal of an appeal for want of prosecution); Freeman v Rabinov [1981] VR 539 ; Nixon v W Phelan & Son Pty Ltd [1959] VR 83 . However, it was circumvented in others by, for example, distinguishing cases where the order had not been entered (Baines v State Bank of New South Wales (1985) 2 NSWLR 729 at 735); where it had not been executed (Manley Estates Ltd v Benedek [1941] 1 All ER 248); where the order was purely interlocutory and did not purport to end the proceedings (Douglas v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 126); or where an appeal lay from the judgment — even though the time for appeal may have expired (Carter v Stubbs (1880) 6 QBD 116; Composite Buyers Ltd v JC Taylor Constructions Pty Ltd [1983] 2 VR 311; Link Blocks Pty Ltd v Fullin [1986] WAR 187 ). Furthermore the decision in Whistler v Hancock, above was overruled by the English Court of Appeal in Samuels v Linzi Dresses Ltd [1981] QB 115 after taking account of the express power to extend time contained in a provision such as UCPR r 1.12 . The same approach has since been taken in New Zealand: Champtaloup v Northern Districts Aero Club Inc [1980] 1 NZLR 673; in New South Wales: Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (1986) 7 NSWLR 319; in Western Australia: Biala Pty Ltd v Mallina Holdings Ltd [1989] 2 WAR 381 (extension of time granted after the entry of judgment); and in the High Court: FAI General Insurance Co Ltd v Southern Cross Exploration NL (1988) 165 CLR 268; 77 ALR 411; BC8802594 . In the latter case the High Court said that where a power to extend time is conferred in general terms, such as those contained in UCPR r 1.12 , the discretion thus conferred should be exercised according to the particular circumstances of each case and the power to extend should not be arbitrarily restricted so as to preclude the setting aside of even a final judgment or order; see also Paino v Hofbauer (1988) 13 NSWLR 193 at 197 (extension of the time stipulated in terms of settlement).

There is a limited power to consider matters that occur after the entry of judgment. Thus a permanent injunction may be suspended if the law or underlying facts materially change: Permewan Wright Consolidated Pty Ltd v AG (NSW); Ex rel Franklin Stores Pty Ltd (1978) 35 NSWLR 365 .

level.toc-caption: [36.16.85] Winding up orders made in the absence of a party

heading.title: Winding up orders made in the absence of a party

p.text: An application to set aside a winding up order made in the absence of the company should be made pursuant to this rule and not by way of appeal to the Court of Appeal: Re Rick Wilson & Co Pty Ltd (1982) 7 ACLR 354; 1 ACLC 566 at 569. Alternatively, an application to stay or terminate the winding up could be made under s 482(1A)(a) of the Corporations Act.

Consistent with the general principles discussed in [36.16.15] and [36.16.20], the absence of the company is not itself sufficient to warrant the exercise of the power to set aside a winding up order. The company must be able to show an additional factor sufficient to warrant setting aside the winding up order: Gyrro Pty Ltd v Deputy Commissioner of Taxation [2009] FCA 1477; BC200911167 (directors inattention not sufficient explanation); Workers Compensation Nominal Insurer v Detailed Flooring Pty Ltd (2010) 80 ACSR 1; [2010] NSWSC 1056; BC201006769 (company’s failure to lodge current address details with ASIC — insufficient explanation); Boral Resources (NSW) Pty Ltd v Urban 8 Constructions Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 217; BC201102151 (defendant misinformed of the time and location of the proceedings — order set aside).

Where an order is set aside or varied under the present rule, the court should make an order under r 36.4(3) specifying the date the new order takes effect. It will usually be appropriate to order that the new order take effect as of the date of the original order: Re Future Life Enterprises Pty Ltd (1994) 33 NSWLR 559 .

A decision of a superior court is valid and enforceable until it is set aside. If the order is set aside the order itself ceases to have any effect. Thus if a conviction is set aside on appeal the appellant’s position at law is to be determined as if the conviction had never occurred: Cmr for Railways (NSW) v Cavanough (1935) 53 CLR 220; [1935] ALR 304 . But if steps have been taken based upon the efficacy of the order the question whether what has been done can be undone will depend upon the availability of other remedies: Wilde v Australian Trade Equipment Co Pty Ltd (1981) 145 CLR 590; 34 ALR 148 and the court may in appropriate circumstances make orders which follow from the operation, as distinct from the validity of the earlier order: for example, Nationwide News Pty Ltd v Samalot Enterprises Pty Ltd (No 2) (1986) 5 NSWLR 227; 10 ACLR 748 (liquidators remuneration).

The court's discretion extends to terms on which it will set aside or vary a judgment. Again, the matter is discretionary, but it is not unusual for terms to include an order that the defendant pay the costs of the application and the costs of steps rendered useless by the judgment being set aside: Federal Bank v Bate (1889) 5 WN (NSW) 67; Burgoine v Taylor (1878) 9 Ch D 1 ; Cockle v Joyce (1877) 7 Ch D 56 ; Passmore v Minahan (1887) 13 VLR 262 . If it appears that the plaintiff obtained the judgment or order irregularly (Water Conservation and Irrigation Commission v Simpson (No 2) (1917) 34 WN (NSW) 83) or has been unreasonable either in signing judgment (Coburne v Brotchie (1890) 16 VLR 6; Bushby v MacKenzie (1919) 19 SR (NSW) 104 ) or in refusing to consent to the judgment being set aside (Gorman v Mathew (1897) 13 WN (NSW) 225 ; Water Conservation and Irrigation Commission v Simpson (No 2) (1917) 34 WN (NSW) 83); costs may be ordered against the plaintiff. If irregular, tardy or unreasonable conduct on the part of both parties has contributed to the entry of the judgment, it may be appropriate to order that the costs of the application be costs in the proceedings: Commercial Traders Ltd v Furness [1962] NSWR 291; (1962) 79 WN (NSW) 528 . Other terms which may be imposed include limitation on the matters which may be pleaded in the defence: Federal Bank v Bate (1889) 5 WN (NSW) 67; but see Pooley v O'Connor (1912) 28 TLR 460. In a proper case the court may order that the defendant pay the amount in dispute into court, though this is unusual: Zeutmint Pty Ltd v Scottish Amicable Life Assurance [1984] 3 NSWLR 293; Rooke v Day (1907) 24 WN (NSW) 127 ; Term Sales Pty Ltd v Joseph (1949) 67 WN (NSW) 44 ; Watt v Barnett (1878) 3 QBD 183 and Watt v Barnett (1878) 3 QBD 363.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.17] r 36.17 Correction of judgment or order (″slip rule″) (cf SCR Part 20, rule 10; DCR Part 17, rule 10; LCR Part 16, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Correction of judgment or order ("slip rule") (cf SCR Part 20, rule 10; DCR Part 17, rule 10; LCR Part 16, rule 10)

p.text: If there is a clerical mistake, or an error arising from an accidental slip or omission, in a judgment or order, or in a certificate, the court, on the application of any party or of its own motion, may, at any time, correct the mistake or error.
Legislation cited in [36.17.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.11.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 133, s 56.

This rule is the only provision that explicitly permits the correction of an order or judgment that has been formally entered under UCPR r 36.11 , and thus become enforceable in accordance with CPA s 133 . It is commonly known as the "slip rule" — because it is expressed to apply only to the correction of errors that arise from "a clerical mistake, or an accidental slip or omission". That description connotes a limitation on the scope of the rule that has been said to preclude its application to mistakes that are the consequence of a deliberate decision: Expo Aluminium (NSW) Pty Ltd v Pateman Pty Ltd (No 2) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Meagher and Samuels JJA, 29 April 1991, unreported, BC9102061). The rule is thoroughly discussed in Newmont Yandal Operations Pty Ltd v The J Aron Corp [2007] NSWCA 195; BC200706351 ; Arnett v Holloway [1960] VR 22 , and see also Re Army and Navy Hotel (1886) 31 Ch D 644 ; Ivanhoe Gold Corp Ltd v Symonds (1906) 4 CLR 642; [1906] HCA 71 ; Barker v Purvis (1886) 57 LT 131; Bright v Sellor [1904] 1 KB 6 ; Ninnis v Miller [1905] VLR 669; (1905) 11 ALR 479 ; Armitage v Parsons [1908] 2 KB 410 ; Brew v Whitlock (No 3) [1968] VR 504 .

In its primary connotation, the slip rule applies where the fact of the error, mistake omission or slip is a matter upon which no real difference of opinion can exist. It can apply even if there are different possible “corrections”, provided the choice between them does not involve a matter of controversy of substance or require the exercise of an independent discretion: Elyard Corp Pty Ltd v DDB Needham Sydney Pty Ltd (1995) 61 FCR 385 at 390–2; 133 ALR 206; 18 ACSR 807; BC9501558 ; Newmont Yandal Operations Pty Ltd v The J Aron Corp [2007] NSWCA 195; BC200706351 at [140], [142], [185], [194] ; Arnett v Holloway [1960] VR 22 ; Re Army and Navy Hotel (1886) 31 Ch D 644 ; Ivanhoe Gold Corp Ltd v Symonds (1906) 4 CLR 642; [1906] HCA 71 ; Brew v Whitlock (No 3), above, at 506. A criterion suggested for determining whether a proposed correction is justified is the hypothetical enquiry as to whether the supposed error, if it had been drawn to the attention of the court or the parties at the relevant time, would have been corrected as a matter of course: Hatton v Harris [1892] AC 547 at 558 . Applying this criterion, a judgment or order can be corrected or set aside after entry if the judge misinterpreted the facts or was misled: see Hall v Harris (1900) 25 VLR 455 at 457; 6 ALR 10 ; Yore Contractors Pty Ltd v Holcon Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Rogers CJ, Comm Div, 17 July 1989, unreported, BC8901954) (misunderstanding of counsel's submissions — judgment set aside but not because of a mere reconsideration of a previous finding: Mutual Shipping Corp v Bayshore Shipping Co Ltd [1985] 1 All ER 520; [1985] 1 WLR 625 at 633 (misattribution of evidence — judgment ordered for wrong party).

A necessary corollary of the criterion suggested in the preceding paragraph is that the “slip rule” does not confer a power to supplement or vary final orders by making substantive alterations to determine points that were not argued, considered or decided at the hearing: Campbell v Brisbane City Council (1967) 14 LGRA 305 ; Lauer v Briggs (No 2) (1928) 28 SR (NSW) 389; (1928) 45 WN (NSW) 110 ; D'Angola v Rio Pioneer Gravel Co Pty Ltd [1977] 2 NSWLR 227 ; In the Marriage of Bailey (1990) 99 FLR 419; 14 Fam LR 125; (1990) FLC ¶92-145.

Despite the reference to “clerical mistake” the “slip rule” also applies, disjunctively, to errors arising from “an accidental slip or omission”. The reality is that the distinction between a deliberate decision and an “accidental slip or omission” is not always clear. For example, it has been held that the “slip rule” is not confined to corrections that merely give effect to the expressed reasons for decision: Elyard Corp Pty Ltd v DDB Needham Sydney Pty Ltd (1995) 61 FCR 385 at 390–2; 18 ACSR 807; 133 ALR 206; BC9501558 ; Akron Securities Ltd v Iliffe (No 3) (NSWCA, Mason P, Priestley and Meagher JJA, No 40524/94, 25 August 1997, unreported, BC9704809). Neither is it confined to cases where the "mistake, error slip or omission" is that of the court itself. Thus in Navimprex Centrala Navala v George Moundreas & Co SA, referred to in (1994) 58 ALJ 114, the English Court of Appeal held that the rule permitted the correction of a clerical error in a judgment where this had arisen as a consequence of an accidental slip or omission by a party’s legal advisers. See also Muir v Jenks [1913] 2 KB 412 ; L Shaddock & Assocs Pty Ltd v Parramatta City Council (No 2) (1982) 151 CLR 590; 43 ALR 473; 56 ALJR 875; BC8200124 ; Commonwealth v McCormack (1984) 155 CLR 273; 55 ALR 185; 58 ALJR 513; BC8400476 ; Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Tectran Corp Pty Ltd (1988) 77 ALR 190; 62 ALJR 151; BC8802659 ; Craigmyle v Inchcape [1942] 1 Ch 394; Steinmetz & Steinmetz (No 2) (1981) FLC 91-079 at 76,562; In the Marriage of Bailey (1990) 99 FLR 419; 14 Fam LR 125; (1990) FLC 92–145. at 78,008 ; Whereat v Whereat (FamCA, Lawrie J, 23 August 1991, unreported).

The fundamental purpose of the slip rule is to confer a power to correct mistakes and errors. It is consistent with that general purpose, especially in the light of direction in CPA s 56 , to interpret the concept of “accidental slip or omission” as extending to permit the correction of an order whose consequences are contrary to those intended by the court: Newmont Yandal Operations Pty Ltd v The J Aron Corp [2007] NSWCA 195; BC200706351 at [114], [185], [194], (orders varied to avoid unintended estoppel in related proceedings). Alternatively, such a power of correction might be regarded as necessarily incidental to the effective exercise of a court’s jurisdiction: Blacker v National Australia Bank Ltd [2000] FCA 1011; BC200004198 ; Newmont Yandal Operations Pty Ltd v The J Aron Corp, above at [70], at [71], [185], [194].

level.toc-caption: [36.17.10] Example of the application of the slip rule

p.text: Legislation cited in [36.17.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 36.16(3A)).

heading.title: Example of the application of the slip rule

p.text: Examples of the inherent or statutory power being exercised in relation to the formal content of orders include:

to correct an order on the ground that the consequences are contrary to those intended by the court: (Blacker v National Australia Bank Ltd [2000] FCA 1011; BC200004198 ; Newmont Yandal Operations Pty Ltd v J Aaron Corporation [2007] NSWCA 195; BC200706351 );
to insert an order made by the judge but omitted from the minute (Re Short; Short v Short (1902) 8 ALR (CN) 30);
to correct a declaration of what assets were owned by the defendant (Gikas v Papanayiotou [1977] 2 NSWLR 944 );
to delete an order which was not made at the hearing (Tauro v Tauro (1897) 14 WN (NSW) 113);
to amend an order which purported to be in respect of two claims in the action when only one had been tried (Ivanhoe Gold Corp Ltd v Symonds (1906) 4 CLR 642 );
amendment to substitute the correct name of a party (Pearlman (Veneers) SA (Pty) Ltd v Bartels [1954] 3 All ER 659; [1954] 1 WLR 1457 );

to amend an order to insert the words “by the plaintiff forthwith”: Capital Finance Australia Ltd v Chief Executive Officer of Customs [2007] NSWSC 1368; BC200710326 (original orders revoked and replaced with new orders incorporating the change — made alternatively under UCPR r 36.16(3A)) .
Examples of the inherent or statutory power being exercised in relation to dates and times include:
amending an injunction to limit the time of its application (Shipwright v Clements (1890) 63 LT 160; 38 WR 746);
amending a maintenance order to run only during the spouse's life instead of joint lives (Harrison v Harrison (1887) 12 PD 130);
to insert a date for compliance with an order where it had been omitted from the order (Re Walsh (1983) 83 ATC 4147; 14 ATR 59 );

to amend a wrong figure or date in the orders where the parties and the judge both used the same wrong figure or date but the correct figure had been available (Re JW Challand Pty Ltd (1945) 62 WN (NSW) 166 ; Re Bickford Joinery Pty Ltd (1974) 7 SASR 438 );
to correct a wrong date in orders where the judge had specified "the second Wednesday in February" (Tye v Lansell (1900) 25 VLR 462 );

to amend the wrong date on the formal judgment of the court arising out of the certificate of costs assessor filed in the registry of the Local Court: Scope Data Systems Pty Ltd v Goman [2008] NSWSC 42; BC200800590 .
Examples of the inherent or statutory power being exercised in relation to the amount of damages include:
to correct the amount of an award of damages for mathematical error (Storey & Keers Pty Ltd v Johnstone (1987) 9 NSWLR 446 ): Esposito v Commonwealth (1988) 8 ACTR 9);
amendment to order repayment of moneys paid by a defendant where subsequent appeal was upheld (Commonwealth v McCormack (1984) 155 CLR 273; 55 ALR 185; BC8400476 ).
Examples of the inherent or statutory power being exercised in relation to interest include:
amendment involving the recalculation of interest (Barker v Purvis (1886) 57 LT 131; Ninnis v Miller [1905] VLR 669 ; but see Brew v Whitlock (No 3) [1968] VR 504 );

amendment to permit a claim for interest to be added to the amount of the judgment (L Shaddock & Assocs Pty Ltd v Parramatta City Council (No 2) (1982) 151 CLR 590; 43 ALR 473; BC8200124 ; Tak Ming Co Ltd v Yee Sang Metal Suppliers Co [1972] 1 WLR 300 at 304); (Although in Hanave Pty Ltd v LFOT Pty Ltd (2004) 136 FCR 566 at 568 and 576; BC200404300 the Full Court of the Federal Court held that the slip rule cannot be applied where a solicitor’s failure to claim interest was due to ignorance rather than inadvertence.)
Examples of the inherent or statutory power being exercised in relation to costs include:

amendment to include a proper order for costs (Armitage v Parsons [1908] 2 KB 410 ; Adams and Harvey Ltd v International Maritime Supplies Ltd [1967] 1 All ER 533; [1967] 1 WLR 445 ); including the reserved costs of an interlocutory application that had been overlooked at the final hearing: Fritz v Hobson (1979) 14 Ch D 542 at 561–2);
to clarify a costs order to indicate it included costs of a special case (Commissioner of Taxes v British Australian Wool Realisation Assn Ltd [1932] VLR 109 );
to correct a certificate of taxation where the solicitor omitted to include fees paid to a referee in his bill of costs (Chessum & Sons v Gordon [1901] 1 KB 694 at 698 );
to rectify the failure of counsel to apply for an order for costs incurred before the issue of a summons (Re Inchcape [1942] Ch 394; [1942] 2 All ER 157 );

to insert a reference to costs of remission to a judge for assessment of damages in a costs order, where those costs had been mistakenly overlooked when the order was made: (Barrell Insurances Pty Ltd v Pennant Hills Restaurants Pty Ltd (1983) 49 ALR 384; 58 ALJR 51; BC8300113 .)

There is an inherent power to vary any order or judgment that does not reflect the true intent of the court: L Shaddock & Assocs Pty Ltd v Parramatta City Council (No 2) (1982) 151 CLR 590; 43 ALR 473; BC8200124 ; or which is apprehended to have consequences contrary to those intended by the actual decision: Newmont Yandal Operations Pty Ltd v J Aron Corporation [2007] NSWCA 195; BC200706351 esp at [17]–[19], [67]–[83]; Gikas v Papanayiotou [1977] 2 NSWLR 944 ; Storey & Keers Pty Ltd v Johnstone (1987) 9 NSWLR 446 ; R v Michael [1976] QB 414 . Even aside from cases involving “corrections” of that kind, there is also an inherent power to set aside an order, even if it has been entered: Taylor v Taylor (1979) 143 CLR 1; 25 ALR 418 (inherent jurisdiction to set aside a judgment obtained by default); Haig v Minister administering the National Parks and Wildlife Act (1994) 85 LGERA 143 ; Commonwealth v McCormack (1984) 155 CLR 273; 55 ALR 185 (mistaken overpayment); R v Bow Street Magistrate; Ex parte Pinochet (No 2) [2000] 1 AC 119; [1999] 1 All ER 577 (allegation of bias of member of House of Lords). As to the application of this principle to the Court of Appeal see Wentworth v Rogers (No 9) (1987) 8 NSWLR 388 ; New South Wales Bar Assn v Smith (NSWCA, Full Court, 7 June 1991, unreported, BC9102691); Rajski v Bainton (NSWCA, 6 September 1991, unreported, BC9100995); Taylor v Lawrence [2003] QB 528; [2002] 2 All ER 353 at [53]–[56] . In an exceptional case the principle of finality was held to be inapplicable where judgment had been entered by one of the parties with the intention of depriving the court of jurisdiction to deal with an outstanding application by the other party. The entry of judgment was held an abuse of process and set aside: TJM Products Pty Ltd v A & P Tyres Pty Ltd (1987) 17 FCR 390; 78 ALR 579 .

Amendments made in the exercise of the power conferred by the slip rule operate from the date of the original orders: Elyard Corp Pty Ltd v DDB Needham Sydney Pty Ltd (1995) 61 FCR 385; 133 ALR 206; (1995) 14 ACLC 50; BC9501558 ; Mailman v Challenge Bank Ltd (NSWSC, Cohen J, 16 April 1992, unreported) (formal orders inconsistent with relevant parts of the judge's reasons); Rajski v Bainton (NSWCA, 6 September 1991, BC9100995, unreported)). Consequently, the court will not make an order for amendment where the rights of third parties are affected by the amendment or where otherwise it would be inexpedient or inequitable: The Belleaim (1885) 10 PD 161 ; Hammond v Schofield [1891] 1 QB 453 ; Hatton v Harris [1892] AC 547 ; Stewart v Rhodes [1900] 1 Ch 386 ; Permanent Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (Executor estate of Andrews) v Stocks & Holdings (Canberra) Pty Ltd (1976) 15 ACTR 45; 28 FLR 195 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.18] r 36.18 Variation of judgment or order against party operating under unregistered business name (cf SCR Part 64, rule 7; DCR Part 46, rule 6; LCR Part 35, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Variation of judgment or order against party operating under unregistered business name (cf SCR Part 64, rule 7; DCR Part 46, rule 6; LCR Part 35, rule 6)

p.text: In any proceedings in which judgment has been given, or an order made, against a person under a business name, the court may vary the judgment or order so as to make it a judgment or order against the person in the person’s own name.
Notice of motion for a direction under subrule (1) must be personally served on the person.
